problem: If $f(x)$ is a polynomial of degree 3, and $g(x)$ is a polynomial of degree 5, then what is the degree of polynomial $2f(x) + 4g(x)$?
model_solution:
Step 1: The degree of a polynomial is determined by the highest power of x in the polynomial. Since f(x) is a polynomial of degree 3 and g(x) is a polynomial of degree 5, the highest power of x in the polynomial 2f(x) + 4g(x) will be determined by the term with the highest power of x.
Step 2: The polynomial with the highest power of x will determine the degree of the new polynomial. Since both f(x) and g(x) are polynomials, the term with the highest power of x from g(x) will have a higher power than the term with the highest power of x from f(x).
Step 3: The degree of the polynomial 2f(x) + 4g(x) will be 5.
Step 4: The leading coefficient of the polynomial with the highest power of x will be the sum of the leading coefficients of g(x) and 0 (since the leading coefficient of f(x) is 0 due to its lower degree).
Step 5: The degree of the polynomial 2f(x) + 4g(x) will be 5.
Step 6: The degree of the polynomial 2f(x) + 4g(x) will be 5.
Step 7: The degree of the polynomial 2f(x) + 4g(x) will be 5.
Step 8: The degree of the polynomial 2f(x) + 4g(x) will be 5.
Step 9: The degree of the polynomial 2f(x) + 4g(x) will be 5.
Step 10: The degree of the polynomial $2f(x) + 4g(x)$ will be 5.
